Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
American Institutes for Research (AIR) will extend and evaluate the CS 10K Community (CS10KC) a platform for facilitating community and professional development among teachers in NSF-supported CS 10K projects. The goal of this project is to increase the quality and volume of community activity; improve the usability and utility of the platform; and add validated online assessments of computational thinking. By contributing to the growth and professional improvement of the teaching workforce, the CS10KC will help lead to broadened participation in high school computer science education, particularly among students from underrepresented groups. This expansion of opportunity for high school students, in turn, increases the likelihood that more diverse students will earn computer science degrees and pursue computing and other STEM careers.

CS10KC will contribute to scaling up training and support for current and new HS CS teachers across the country through providing access to instructional resources developed by projects and individual teachers, convening discussions and online events on topics aligned with challenges that teachers face, facilitating collaboration of teachers to generate new resources and pedagogical approaches using online tools, and providing online assessments of computational thinking aligned with the curriculum of the courses. CS10KC will provide a national picture of where, how, and by whom the Exploring Computer Science and AP CS Principles courses are being taught. CS10KC will result in a richer understanding of the growth of teaching courses designed to broaden participation in computer science and the effects that online support for teachers is having on that growth.

Institution.Name: American Institutes for Research in the Behavioral Sciences
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: AMERICAN INSTITUTES FOR RESEARCH IN THE BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES

Performance_Institution.Name: American Institutes for Research in the Behavioral Sciences

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Computer Science (CS) for All Teachers project enriched and deepened the virtual community of practice (CoP) originally developed by American Institutes for Research (AIR) in 2013, redesigned in 2015, and rebranded from its original name as the CS10K Community in 2016. Through the virtual CoP, AIR supported prekindergarten through Grade 12 (PreK–12) teachers interested in computer science education in discussing their burning questions, sharing their teaching experiences, searching for resources, and learning new instructional strategies from their colleagues—all to ensure access to computer science for all students.

CS for All Teachers developed diverse strategies for engaging its 4,400 community members. More than 100 teacher leaders and computer science education researchers were invited to host 55 webinars on various topics, resulting in more than 1,500 attendees and 4,763 total recording views. These individuals also facilitated discussion groups, curated resources, and assisted in answering community-generated questions. As a result, the site netted an average of 6,967 user sessions and 25,776 pageviews each month. Total users over the three year period surpassed 25,000. These data were tracked on a monthly basis using Google Analytics. The CS for All Teachers’ Twitter account (@CSforAllTchrs) enabled more than 2,500 followers to stay up to date on major events in computer science education and the community, while the MailChimp e-newsletter service offered a monthly update on engagement activities for an average of 2,500 subscribers.

Through a partnership with SRI Education, assessments and related products for the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) course were developed and disseminated via the community space. A new online delivery system was also implemented and tested. A small inquiry group provided the opportunity for two teachers to develop facilitation skills for leading inquiry groups and participating teachers to foster new skills in finding evidence of student learning.

As technology becomes more prevalent in our daily lives, computer science knowledge continues to grow in importance. Virtual CoPs, like CS for All Teachers, offer one venue for providing teachers across the United States with the support necessary to gain the knowledge and skills that will ensure all students have access to computer science. CS for All Teachers transcended time and space to connect PreK–12 teachers with resources and to build networks for collaborative problem solving and creativity. SRI’s work directly supported the goal of scaling ECS and expanding its adoption by teachers through the availability of assessment resources. This expansion of opportunity for high school students, in turn, increases the likelihood that more diverse students will earn computer science degrees and pursue computing and other STEM careers.

Building a foundational understanding of what computer science teachers in the field are actually doing and experiencing in their classrooms is critical for informing and cultivating effective support mechanisms. The lessons learned from the management and facilitation of CS for All Teachers about how to prepare and support teachers to successfully teach computer science can help to inform the design of professional development and preservice programs for the next generation of computer science teachers. This is especially critical for a content area, like computer science, that lacks sufficient numbers of teachers with the content and pedagogical knowledge to teach the subject. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2017
Modified by: Melissa Rasberry
